comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: State Records NSW has two versions of this photo - investigator.records.nsw.gov.au/asp/photosearch/photo.asp... and with people - investigator.records.nsw.gov.au/asp/photosearch/photo.asp...

comment.author: 47201412@N02
comment._content: Don't forget the State Library of Victoria! Caraher Stairs, Lower Fort St. (c.1901) [SLV: H42656, b28023]

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/pellethepoet] I have been trying to find out exactly when the George Street tramway (opened December 1899 to Circular Quay) was extended round to Argyle Place. Any ideas? See route on this 1903 map - www.nla.gov.au/apps/cdview?pi=nla.map-rm1635-sd&rgn=0...

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: Found it! The Millers Point extension opened in August 1901; the SMH for Saturday 17/8/1901 has this short article about test runs - trove.nla.gov.au/ndp/del/article/14404169 . Presumably the track, poles and wires were there a few weeks earlier. That might prove useful in dating several photos of The Rocks, along with the contemporary Will Daley posters (btw reminds me of that old joke - BILL POSTERS WILL BE PROSECUTED)..

comment.author: 47201412@N02
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/beachcomberaustralia] Well done on finding that article on Trove - I scoured it last night without success. I did however find this 1897 proposal by Norman Selfe for a major train station in The Rocks (in anticipation of a future bridge to the North Shore), which would have involved large scale RESUMPTION (funny that!) - trove.nla.gov.au/ndp/del/article/14104874. May be of interest ...

comment.author: 47201412@N02
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/beachcomberaustralia] Here's your tram line along Lower Fort Street: Lower Fort Street looking north from Argyle Cut (c.1901) [SLV: H42656, b28020] And here's a perty one - looking down the Caraher Stairs (by Cazneaux!) nla.gov.au/nla.pic-vn4802972

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content:
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/pellethepoet]  Interesting photos - Can you see a tram pole near the 'Hero of Waterloo' which might help date the State Records NSW photo?  I am trying to prove that it is 1901 - not content with "c.1902".

That Cazneaux shows on the right of photo (and as empty land in the photo above) this block of "Workmens Dwellings" 1916. -

[http://www.flickr.com/photos/state-records-nsw/3907734317/]
